track_a.assessment_viability_summary: High-quality extraction and classification enable confident credibility assessment with approach-specific anchors. Comprehensive 8-pass extraction with validation. All passes completed, all bidirectional mappings consistent, 100% source verification.
improvement_opportunities: Consider ORCID availability check via publisher metadata
Note licence specification practices for deposited materials
Implement formal metrics (TCI, ESD, RIS) for corpus comparison

signals.summary: Excellent comprehensibility for an inductive methodological paper. Research questions and goals explicit, pattern descriptions clear and well-bounded, key technical terms defined, logical progression from observations to patterns to interpretation transparent.
strengths: Explicit dual research goals (presenting method + demonstrating capability)
Well-defined technical terminology (skipgram, PMI, n-gram)
Carefully bounded pattern claims with explicit scope constraints
Traceable argument structure from evidence to claims
Clear distinction between methodological and empirical claims
weaknesses: Some archaeological domain terminology assumed
Bouissac framework not fully operationalised to specific analyses
Implicit transition from semiotic to socio-political interpretation
signals.justification: Scored 83 (Excellent Comprehensibility band for inductive research). Meets 80-100 anchor criteria: research questions explicit, pattern descriptions clear and bounded, key terms defined, logical progression transparent. Minor deductions for assumed domain knowledge.
signals.approach_context: For inductive methodological papers, comprehensibility emphasises clear pattern descriptions rather than hypothesis precision. This paper excels at pattern clarity - findings about motif co-occurrence are precisely described.

signals.summary: Excellent transparency for a computational methodology paper. Research design explicitly stated as exploratory/demonstrative, data collection and transformation documented, analysis workflow specified, data and code openly available in Zenodo with DOIs.
strengths: Explicit design statement framing paper as methodology demonstration
Documented data source (Płonka catalogue) and transformation procedures
Reproducible analysis workflow with R version and package dependencies
Data and code openly available in two Zenodo repositories with DOIs
Explicit limitations acknowledged including 6 implicit assumptions
weaknesses: Classification scheme not independently validated (inter-coder reliability not tested)
Missing computational environment specification (no containerisation)
No explicit licence for deposited materials
Missing author ORCIDs
signals.justification: Scored 82 (Excellent Transparency band for inductive research). Meets 80-100 anchor criteria: clear documentation of exploratory goals, comprehensive data procedures, workflow documented, data archived. Minor deductions for environment specification gaps.
signals.approach_context: For inductive research, transparency emphasises workflow documentation and data archiving over pre-registration (not expected for exploratory work). This paper meets inductive transparency standards excellently.

signals.summary: Good plausibility for a methodological paper. Method grounded in established computational linguistics, null finding consistent with domain expectations, interpretations appropriately cautious with alternative explanations considered.
strengths: Method grounded in established computational linguistics (skipgram, PMI)
Bouissac's semiotic framework provides theoretical basis
Null finding (no semiotic structure) consistent with archaeological expectations
Alternative interpretations considered (neutral cultural transmission)
Interpretations appropriately hedged with modal language
weaknesses: Untested assumptions affect plausibility of method claims
Socio-political interpretation for Ertebølle cluster is speculative
Limited engagement with counter-evidence for the Ertebølle exception
signals.justification: Scored 78 (Good Plausibility band for inductive research). Meets 60-79 anchor criteria: patterns consistent with domain knowledge, interpretations grounded in theory, alternative explanations considered, appropriate hedging. Does not reach 80+ due to untested assumptions.
signals.approach_context: For inductive research, plausibility assesses whether discovered patterns fit domain expectations. The absence of consistent motif combinations is expected based on archaeological understanding of Mesolithic art.

signals.summary: Good validity for a methodological demonstration paper. Substantial corpus (483 objects) provides statistical power, case study demonstrates method capability, though limitations in data quality (typological dating, classification reliability) are acknowledged.
strengths: Substantial corpus (483 objects, nearly half of European Mesolithic portable art)
Quantitative findings clearly presented with tables and figures
Method capability demonstrated through successful pipeline execution
Limitations explicitly acknowledged
weaknesses: Typological dating used as proxy (most objects not directly radiocarbon dated)
Classification scheme not independently validated
Gap between method demonstration and archaeological conclusions
Limited positive validation (only Ertebølle cluster shows signal)
signals.justification: Scored 72 (Good Validity band for inductive research). Meets 60-79 anchor criteria: sampling generally adequate, evidence quantity supports claims, limitations acknowledged. Does not reach 80+ due to dating and classification quality limitations.
signals.approach_context: For methodological papers, key validity question is case study adequacy. This paper provides adequate validation for a first demonstration - technical pipeline works and null finding is interpretable.

signals.summary: Moderate robustness, appropriate for initial method demonstration. Single analytical pipeline without sensitivity testing or alternative method comparison. Parameters documented but not varied.
strengths: Analytical parameters explicitly stated (k=13, R v4.2.2, Quanteda)
Alternative interpretation considered (neutral drift vs. semiotic meaning)
Limitations of binary encoding acknowledged
weaknesses: No sensitivity analysis on k value, n-gram lengths, or frequency thresholds
No alternative methods tested (only skipgram + PMI)
Classification scheme not varied or tested with alternatives
Single corpus (no cross-validation)
signals.justification: Scored 55 (Moderate Robustness band). Meets 40-59 criteria: single approach documented, interpretive alternatives discussed. Does not reach higher bands due to absence of sensitivity testing. Appropriate for novel method demonstration.
signals.approach_context: For methodological papers, robustness is appropriately deemphasised. Primary goal is demonstrating method capability, not exhaustive sensitivity analysis. Future work could address through parameter variation and cross-corpus validation.

signals.summary: Good generalisability with appropriately bounded claims. Case study findings carefully constrained to South Scandinavian Mesolithic corpus. Method transferability framed as potential rather than demonstrated.
strengths: Geographic scope explicit (South Scandinavia defined)
Temporal scope explicit (Mesolithic, 11,000-5950 BP)
Case study vs. method claims clearly distinguished
Transferability framed as potential, not demonstrated
weaknesses: Method transferability claimed but not empirically validated
Null finding may not generalise to other contexts
Sample representativeness assumed rather than examined
signals.justification: Scored 70 (Good Generalisability band for inductive research). Meets 60-79 anchor criteria: scope constraints explicit, sample documented, claims bounded. Does not reach 80+ due to untested transferability claims.
signals.approach_context: For methodological papers, generalisability is appropriately deemphasised. Goal is demonstrating capability on one corpus, not comprehensive generalisation. Paper appropriately avoids over-claiming.

signals.summary: Excellent reproducibility for a computational methodology paper. Data and code openly archived in Zenodo with DOIs, R version and primary package documented, workflow clearly described. Main gaps: no containerisation, incomplete dependency specification.
strengths: Data openly available in Zenodo with DOI (10.5281/zenodo.10623550)
Code openly available in Zenodo with same DOI
R version (4.2.2) and Quanteda package documented
Workflow clearly described enabling independent verification
Expected outputs documented for comparison
weaknesses: No computational environment containerisation
Incomplete dependency specification (only R and Quanteda noted)
No explicit licence for deposited materials
Missing author ORCIDs
signals.justification: Scored 80 (Excellent Reproducibility band for inductive research). Meets 80-100 anchor criteria: data and code archived, workflow documented, key versions noted. Does not reach 85+ due to containerisation and dependency gaps.
signals.approach_context: For computational methodology papers, reproducibility emphasises code sharing and environment documentation. This paper meets expectations well with openly available materials enabling verification.

inputs_available.details: Corpus data in Zenodo (DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.10623550) containing 483 ornamented objects digitised from Płonka (2003) catalogue

code_available.details: R scripts for skipgram analysis deposited in Zenodo. Uses R v4.2.2 and Quanteda package.

environment_specified.details: R version 4.2.2 and Quanteda package documented. Full dependency list not provided. No containerisation.

outputs_documented.details: Tables 1-2 provide frequency distributions and PMI summary statistics. Figures 3-5 show visualisations. These serve as comparison points for reproduction.

reproducibility_readiness.feasibility_rationale: Researcher with R programming experience could reproduce analysis with moderate effort. Standard R environment, open data, straightforward pipeline. Main risk is package version incompatibility over time.
